article_title: Mary O'Grady: Middle-Class Brazilians Are in No Mood to Party
article_text:
When Brazil was awarded the right to host the 2014 World Cup almost seven years ago, the nation's soccer fanatics were elated. But none more so than Brazil's political class, which understood that the tournament would mean a rash of federal spending all over the country.

Yet hosting the World Cup isn't turning out to be a winner for President Dilma Rousseff, who took office in 2010 and is up for re-election in October. Polls now...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Americas columnist Mary Anastasia O'Grady writes that middle-class Brazilians are fed up with President Dilma Rousseff's economic policy failures.
twitter.title: Middle-Class Brazilians Are in No Mood to Party

article_summary:
When Brazil was awarded the right to host the 2014 World Cup almost seven years ago, the nation's soccer fanatics were elated.
Yet hosting the World Cup isn't turning out to be a winner for President Dilma Rousseff, who took office in 2010 and is up for re-election in October.
But none more so than Brazil's political class, which understood that the tournament would mean a rash of federal spending all over the country.
Polls now...
